posts.name: Noah Sookraj
posts.cooked: Hello, over the past few days at our competition our robot has been moving significantly slower than usual. Our robot has generally been running at max speed when we practiced, but now it seems like when it’s on the field that it’s running at 25-30% it’s max speed. The code hasn’t changed at all from when it was running fine before. I’m wondering, since we’re using mk4i l3 swerve modules, if driving on carpet as opposed to driving on floor could result in the wheels not being able to to get enough torque or something? Looking at the ds log files of our matches, it’s looking like 4 slots on our pdh are experiencing really high current draw (many spikes to 80+, 100+ amps in each of the four slots compared to less than 30 amps for the other slots), and while I don’t know for certain which motors they’re corresponding to I’m fairly certain it’s the drive motors. Our robot is a little over 110 pounds (which may not be good since we have l3, which might not perform well over 100 pounds per this post: What mk4i gear ratio should we get? - #3 by nicbamb12 ), and I’m wondering if that combined with the carpet is causing the problem.

link_counts.title: What mk4i gear ratio should we get?

posts.name: Kellan Rohde
posts.cooked: Is the carpet you used at your field at home the same one used at comp? Traction could be a major factor.

posts.name: Kellan Rohde
posts.cooked: Also is your tread worn? Could be another factor.

posts.name: Dilpreet Singh Randhawa
posts.cooked:
No code changes and that you’ve already played an event, where presumably you did not see this issue (which would be on the new carpet) means to me that it’s more likely something changed mechanically or electrically.

Just driving on a different surface (whatever is natural at your workspace vs the carpet) should not cause your robot to suddenly pull a ton of current.

What type of wheels are you using? Have you tried turning the drive wheels by hand to make sure something isn’t binding up across all 4 modules–did you recently reassemble them or do a rewire?

posts.name: Noah Sookraj
posts.cooked: We stupidly never tested our robot on the carpet we had at home—we just had like a tiled floor we used. I’ll have them check tomorrow for tread wear.

posts.name: Noah Sookraj
posts.cooked: We’re using 4 inch colsons I believe. We haven’t tried turning them by hand—again, I’ll have them do that tomorrow. The modules haven’t been reassembled recently, although we did have to rewire our CAN bus at some point due to some bad CAN connections. I’m not entirely certain, but I think we may have been having the problem before that though.
Also check that you haven’t ingested tape into the bevel gears. Something we became well aware of practicing on carpet but you may not have experienced on a floor.

posts.name: Dilpreet Singh Randhawa
posts.cooked: Check to make sure the bolts threading the bevel gear into the colsons wheels aren’t backing out and interfering with something else in the module. That may not be your issue, but it can happen, we have observed that issue. Not on 4 wheels at the same time, but if this has slowly been getting worse, worth checking.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
That’s probably a lot of your problem right there. Robots have a bad habit of reacting differently on different floors.

Just as a silly question, what are your current (timing) current (A) limits set at, and what sort of current (A) were you seeing on the floor?

posts.name: Noah Sookraj
posts.cooked: Through the rev hardware client the amp limit for each motor is 80, but on the software side we have the amount the Sparks can change their output percentage (-1 to 1) limited to at most 0.25 change from what they’re currently reading. I’ve just taken a look back through log files of some of our practice times, and it seems like they also had spikes in the pdh similar to what we’re experiencing now (80-100 amp spikes). I can certainly try lowering the amp limit and seeing if that’ll help at all.

posts.name: Abu
posts.cooked: I don’t know what swerve libraries you’re using, but I would double check all of the .json files. Make sure your coefficient of friction is correct for the carpet.

posts.name: Noah Sookraj
posts.cooked: Unfortunately swerve libraries didn’t work for us so we created our own swerve code. Do you by chance know generally how the coefficient of friction is used to affect the calculations?

posts.name: Noah Sookraj
posts.cooked: It’s looking like our intake ended up sagging down, resulting in it essentially being lower than our wheels and dragging against the ground. I think that that + carpet may be the majority of the problem.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
It doesn’t affect it. If you’re not slipping your wheels, the effect of the driving surace shouldn’t be too great.

Rolling your own library is a little risky and could be why you’re having issues. Make sure to debug it thoroughly with unit tests.

posts.name: Noah Sookraj
posts.cooked: Adding an update, we managed to get the intake moved up a bit so it’s no longer dragging and we drove much faster after that.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
